section.name: Project Structure
section.p:
Hippo ECM is a Maven 2 project consisting of
multiple modules which are hierarchically organized as shown below, each module produces exactly one artifact (file). Modules come in three flavors, depending on the type of artifact they create.

li.p: JAR projects create a jar file that can be used in applications.
WAR projects create an application (a war file) that can be deployed in an application server (tomcat, glassfish, weblogic etc.).
POM projects act as 'glue' for binding together other projects, they don't create anything themselves

section.p: The figure below shows the project layout. Every node in the directory tree constitutes a Maven project of one of these three types. The artifactId matches the project directory layout.

section.name: API
section.p: Hippo ECM specific extensions to the JCR API.

section.name: Repository
section.p: The repository is implemented by the projects bound by the repository project.
section.source: |-- repository Pom | |-- engine Jar Repository core | `-- application War Minimal repository application, all other repository application projects are 'WAR overlays' of this project.

section.name: Frontend
section.p: The frontend plugin architecture is implemented by the projects bound by the frontend project.
section.source: |-- frontend Pom | |-- engine Jar Frontend core | |-- plugins Jar core plugins for a minimal GUI `-- application War Minimal frontend application, all other frontend application projects are 'WAR overlays' of this project. It is configured to start an embedded repository.

section.name: Addons
section.p: All customization is done through the use of addons. Core addons are implemented by the projects under the addon project.

A default available add-on is the reviewed-actions workflow which is a bundling of a repository plugin implementing the workflow logic with a frontend plugin implementing a GUI for user interaction and a common plugin for the interface between the two. Part of the addon is also a test project that acts as a placeholder for integration tests on the addon (plugged in a running repository and/or frontend server)
Hippo CMS 7 is implemented as an assembly of add-ons, the addon projects can be found under the 'addon' directory.
